title: Error 500 while authenticating Gmail with OAuth2
content: This morning, Thunderbird started asking me to log into my Gmail account out of the blue. After pressing Next, the same page opened in Firefox, and after selecting my account there and pressing Next, I simply got a generic page with the title "500. That's an error" and a simple text asking me to try again later. No matter what I do, even trying different browsers, the result is the same. I can access Gmail through Firefox without problem, and my Gmail account worked just fine yesterday with Thunderbird. I have not changed Thunderbird's configuration for months, and OAuth2 authentication has worked without problem since I activated it back in 2022. What can I do?
creator: ajgelado

Usually, it says the email has been send to the previous person I've emailed, even though it hasn't. Can you help in fixing this?

I have attached a screenshot illustrating the issue.

Many thanks in advance
creator: Fuffyfuffy

title: Prevent Compact folder from compacting subfolders
content:
Since the dawn of time, the Compact folder command on the folder context menu has compacted just the selected folder. However, I have noticed that in the latest Thunderbird version (I'm using 115.6.1) the Compact folder starts automatically compacting all subfolders under the current one. This is a big problem for me: under the inbox, which I need to compact fairly often because all messages pass through it, I have literally hundreds of subfolders, some of them dating from more than 20 years ago, when I used Netscape Communicator. Those folders are "read only" (I only have them for reference), and I do not want to modify them in any way, to avoid risking their contents. Thus, I DO NEED for Thunderbird to stop compacting subfolders automatically. Is it possible? How can it be done?

Also, after a folder compacting has started, what's the best way of cancelling it, short of closing Thunderbird? I understand that the compaction process is quite safe, as it copies all data to a fresh file, but would rather not risk data loss.
creator: ajgelado

title: Re-establishing Email Accounts
content:
I'm having trouble re-establishing email accounts in Thunderbird. I managed to drop them in the process of going to version 115; I don't know how but I did.

Now when I try to add them back I can get through the process (Tools > Account Settings > Account Actions > Add E-Mail Account) and enter the user name, email address, and mail server names and port settings for the various domains I use. All goes well until the final phase when it tries to validate the password. The final message says "Unable to log in at server. Probably wrong configuration, username or password."

I've done everything I know to do to fix this. I've changed passwords, checked, re-checked, verified, checked re-checked and re-verified the domain's POP3 and SMTP server names and port addresses all to no avail. I'm having trouble with my ISP's (grandecommunications purchased by Astound Communications) support on issues with email addresses that use their domain (@mygrande.net) but I'm also having the same problem with gmail domain (@gmail.com) addresses.

I would abandon the email addresses if it weren't for the fact that some of the email on servers is critical and needs to be downloaded to my system. Also, I can't log in to some accounts because the companies use 2-step authentication that involves sending codes to my email addresses instead of codes texted to my phone. This has reached near crisis proportions as I cannot reach those companies except online which requires 2-step authentication using those email addresses that I cannot set up again in Thunderbird.

I'm willing to take screenshots at each step if that will be helpful. I'm afraid that I've dealt with the problem for so long that I'm making the same mistake repeatedly but not recognizing that I'm doing so.

Any help will be greatly appreciated.
creator: rabbithutch1

title: current command did not succeed mail server responded unknown source folder
content:
Full error message: The current command did not succeed.The mail server for account condobloke@gmail.comresponded : Unknown source folder (failure) History: out of the blues a group(18) folders decided to shift camp...instead pof being where they usually are in my list....they were found a further few inches down the page. All the info they contain is still there. The trash folder has been replaced by a "bin"...this is not a problem it just begs the question...why ?

Earlier today I received a message from google saying "schedule archive of google data started for condobloke gmail.com....and it marked the time and date that was initiated as today at 14:47pm

I did not initiate this. So, i changed my password (16 characters)....lengthened it 28. No one else has access to my passwords. No one.

In the middle of changing password and getting the show on the road again, I received an email from google asking me to confirm that I was allowing Thunderbird access to my gmail. (I usually see that when I am setting up a fresh gmail account and accessing that via Thunderbird.....I set up Thunderbird on 4 pc's in the house) "Mozilla Thunderbird Email Has access to Gmail, Google Calendar, Google Contacts"....The alternative email for your account was removed. If you didn't remove it, you should check what happened.""

The alternative account they are speaking about is condobloke@gmail.com I have one other account which is apparently unscathed So, condobloke etc has been reinstated....successfully. new password "" Google Mozilla Thunderbird Email was granted access to your linked Google Account condobloke@gmail.com

I can always wait to see if something comes down the line from google overnight.....maybe reinstating the arrangement of my folders?....that just might be wishful thinking !

I dont mind admitting I am a bit lost.

Brian

Ive installed a MIME-certificate from Sectigo in Thunderbird 115.6.1 on Pop OS (flatpak).

In attached image 2 and 3 it shows that the application has imported the cert and that its valid until 2025.

Any tips or input is helpful.

Also under Security Devices I have a PKCS#11 module that I have logged in to, but I dont see how that could affect PKCS#12 certs but I read in some guide that I had to do that. Which also apparently mean that master password is set for protecting credentials in the application, so I have to provide that password when opening Tunderbird.

title: Cannot add Gmail to Thunderbird, "Unable to log in at server"
content:
I am trying to migrate from Mailspring to Thunderbird, yet have problems with adding my Google/Gmail accounts.

When I try to add a new account with my email and password, Thunderbird detects the IMAP details as follows: INCOMING SERVER Protocol: IMAP Hostname: imap.gmail.com Port: 993 Connection security: SSL/TLS Authentication method: OAuth2 Username: <my email>

OUTGOING SERVER Hostname: smtp.gmail.com Port: 465 Connection security: SSL/TLS Authentication method: OAuth2 Username: <my email>

When I then try to connect, I get the Google sign in popup, where I re-enter my password and grant the access via 2FA. Then, the screen to give Thunderbird read/write permissions for mail, calendar, etc. appears, I click "Allow", the popup closes and Thunderbird tells me: "Unable to log in at server. Probably wrong configuration, username or password."

I have checked other help articles; cookies are allowed, Thunderbird has no stored passwords for Google/Gmail, I have no overly protective antivirus software installed (only Windows Defender), I tried it with/without my VPN off.

I saw older articles mention allowing unsecure apps, yet this has been deprecated by Google in 2022 (I also tried "Password only" instead of "OAuth2", didn't work). I also never got an email from Google that a sign-in request was blocked (only the typical "Did you just sign in?").

Other (non-Google) accounts work fine in Thunderbird, and I only installed it today (so there should be no updates), while another Gmail account of mine doesn't work, either.

I am out of ideas what I could try to get my accounts to work... Can anyone help me?
creator: eric.jacob.2003

title: TB will not recognize profile after upgrade to win 10
content:
I was finally forced to upgrade from win7 (which worked) to win 10 (me no likey) because of a required program which would not even install on win7. After the upgrade, which obliterated my hard drive of several important things, I am reinstalling TB. I always used an NAS directory for Thunderbird, and have email records going back nearly twenty years. I installed TB 115 and have tried several ways to get it to recognize my profile directory on the NAS to no avail. I tried copying data into the default directory the 115 install is looking at. The about:profiles shows it is looking in the correct directory, it produces a parent.lock file in that directory when I run the program. It does not give me my email, or contacts. I do not use the calendar or to-do lists.

My system is an AMD K6-6400K with 16 GB and a 500 GB drive. Though programs are loaded on the drive ALL data is stored in an NAS. There is about 375 GB available on the C drive.

I have used the cmd line to pull up profile manager, added a profile, pointed it to the data that is on the NAS, a parent lock file is created there too but it shows me no mail.

I have edited the profiles.ini file manually to have the program look at the directories, both the NAS and a local directory which has had the old files entered. Neither worked.

I tried opening TB and creating a new profile and pre-loading the info there, nothing. I've been at this for days now. I have uninstalled and removed manually all TB folders and reinstalled older versions to give that a go but without effect. I am no Luddite (Many years ago I owned a system integration, assembly and install company doing networking for the military as a civilian contractor.) but someone has to explain this to me like I am a five year old. There is no reason having my email back should be this difficult!

PLEASE give me a hand?

My TB directory appears in C:\Users\owner\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird My old data folder was on a network drive at M:\Users\owner\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\profiles\k5zbs5az.default When I manually enter the M: address in the profiles.ini file, it "corrects" it to C:\Users\owner\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\ even though the switch 'relative' is off.

[Profile1] Name=default IsRelative=1 Path=Profiles/zpfeu8eu.default Default=1

[Profile0] Name=default-beta IsRelative=0 Path=C:\Users\owner\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird

[General] StartWithLastProfile=0 Version=2

[Install5D388C1349709B37] Default=C:\Users\owner\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird Locked=1

Running the Mozilla application with a specific profile using command line arguments brings up the program but no mail. It creates a lock file in the correct directory, but no joy.

I get no pop up error messages.

title: Profile Made With 32-bit Thunderbird On A Detachable Hard Drive Is Not Directly Useable On 64-bit Versions
content:
I keep my profile on a detachable USD hard drive so I can use Thunderbird on my laptop when I travel just as I do on my desktop. Thunderbird on both of these computers is the 32-bit version and kept up to date (version 115.6.1). I know how to point Thunderbird to use the profile on the USB drive via the profiles.ini configuration. Recently, I bought a new desktop computer and downloaded Thunderbird from the download web page. UNBEKNOWNST TO ME it downloaded the 64-bit version without giving me a notice or a choice. I edited the profile.ini file to point to the profile on the USB drive and it did not work well. The calendars were disabled, no mail folders appeared and no email accounts appeared. My contacts were OK. So, I shut down the new desktop and I put the USB drive in my old desktop, ran the 32-bit Thunderbird and it now looked as dysfunctional as it did on 64-bit Thunderbird. Ooof. Dead in the water.

Fortunately I had a 2-month old backup and restored that profile after renaming the damaged profile folder on the USB hard drive. I then copied over the mail folders from the damaged folder to the restored profile folder so I would have all the latest mail. I also copied over any files in the main folder of the damaged profile that had not been changed by the 64-bit program on the new desktop computer. Fortunately, when I ran 32-bit Thunderbird, all my email from the last 2 months was there. Some recent calendar entries were missing and I had to redo the POP protocol for one of my 5 email accounts I manage with Thunderbird as I did a couple weeks ago. Yay! I immediately backed up the USB hard drive.

So, any clue why this happened? I am planning to make a test on the new desktop. I uninstalled the 64-bit version and installed the 32-bit version. I am going to restore the 32-bit profile folder from the backup to a USB stick with just the profile folder to see if it works as it does on my old desktop and laptop by just editing profile.ini (and installs.ini) as it is on those two systems.
creator: raymond.pilch

title: Unable to log in at server. Probably wrong configuration, username or password.
content:
In trying to set up accounts that I have with my ISP (Astound/Grande communications) - accounts that used to work but need to be set up again due to system problems on my computer after a thunderstorm - I get the error message in the subject line at the end of the account set up process. I get the error repeatedly setting up account after account. I've done this a few hundred times over numerous days. I am extremely careful to ensure spelling is correct, copying and pasting were possible to avoid typos.

The procedure I follow is this (starting with the menu bar): 1) Tools > Account Settings > Account Actions > Add Mail Account 2) Provide name, email address with the correct domain name, and password (copied and pasted from Roboform). 3) Choose Configure Manually and opt for POP3 protocol then provide the hostname, (mail.mygrande.net), port number (110), Connection Security (none; I've also tried Autodetect), and Authentication Method (Autodetect), and, finally entering the relevant email address in the Username field (I've also tried using my name, the same as entered at the beginning under Your Full Name. For the Outgoing Server or SMTP variables the only thing that differs is the port number (587). 4) Click the retest button, which then gives a green panel saying "Looking up information, probing server" and afterward giving the response in a bar with green background "(checkmark) The following settings were found by probing the given server." 5) Click DONE and respond to the warning panel by checking the "I understand the risk" box acknowledging that the servers are not secure. After a long wait, I get the error in the subject: "Unable to log in at server. Probably wrong configuration, username or password."

I initially presumed the problem to lie with the ISP because I don't encounter the problem with gmail addresses or with addresses set up with other email servers; however I've been unsuccessful in resolving the issue over a period of months. So far, Astound/Grande have not taken ownership of the problem despite my attempts to escalate to second level tech support.

It is vexing because several sites I visit online use these email addresses to send codes during their 2-step process for validating my credentials. It is also vexing because I know that messages are resident on my ISP's servers - I see them in their webmail access - that I cannot download to my computer using POP3 protocol.

Please help. If there is additional information - other than passwords - that I can supply, you have only to ask. If there is information I can supply to Astound/Grande for their diagnosis, please provide it and I will be sure they get it.

TIA
creator: rabbithutch1

title: All of my 2023 emails are missing help!!!!!!!!
content: All of my 2023 emails are missing help!!!!!!!!
creator: theresebailey7

title: Highlighting of new messages, and tags on mailboxes, seem random?
content:
Yes, it is a tiny issue, but when new messages are requested or arrive on their own, it seems random whether they will get a tag on the mailbox and be highlighted if I open the mailbox. I have to manually open and peek inside each mailbox of my four servers to know if there is anything there!

Except when I compose a new message - that always puts a tag on the server I'm writing for, and on the Drafts folder. Once I send it, the tag goes away, it doesn't show on the Sent folder.

The attached screenshot shows a rare tag on the top Inbox, but the one highlighted message is from the previous day. None of the newer messages are highlighted! It is always crazy like that...

This is on Arch Linux, 115.6.1 (64-bit) Mozilla Thunderbird for Arch Linux archlinux - 1.0 But it has happened for years...

Does anyone else see this?
creator: LorenAmelang

title: I cannot type an apostrophe anymore. Hereès the problem.
content: It looks like Thunderbird has defaulted to a French Canadian keyboard. I tried to fix it by deleting the Canadian keyboard from Windows, now I just have a US keyboard. But I canèt get it to type an apostrophe or a question mark (seeÉ).
creator: andy.welch
